Input.posts:
Hello Dominic and Al, here is how I understand this chord progression based what I learned at the music academy. I will try to give you my thought process. I think it may be helpful: The first chord can be analyzed as VI6. This raises alarms bell for me as the VI chord is very rarely in first inversion. Indeed as a VI6 chord is so close to a I chord, the specificity of VI is not very present. Therefore it is not used. So I usually tell myself we're not in Kansas anymore i.e. we somehow changed tonality. If you go to the end of the phrase, there is clearly a I chord in F#. So what happened before that If we go back one chord, we have III in F#. This is usually a chord that we don't see in classical piece except in a cycle of fifths progression. However, I know that the III chord in minor is the I chord of the corresponding major mode. Could we be in A major? With this in mind, let's analyze the chord before that. The G# goes to the A and the B goes to the A too. Could G# be a laeding tone and we would have a V in A major (E-G#-B-(D))? Let's look at the melody. The F# could be an appogiatura and the two other notes could be chord tones. If you listen to it, the F# sounds a little bit like an appogiatura. Now the seventh, the D should go to a C on the I chord (A-C-E). Is it the case. No, it goes to a B#. However, this is clearly an appogiatura and where does it lead: to a C. So the seventh resolves itself to a C on another chord than I by the use of the appogiatura. Now if the chord we analyzed as VI6 is actually in A major, we can analyze it as IV6 which for me make much more sense. Let's summarize, we have in A major IV6-V7-I followed by what could be VI. Now the question is did we actually modulate in A major. For me, the answer is no. With the same understanding as a chord that is borrowed from the major or minor mode (e.g. IV major in a minor mode), I would like to understand that as a passage that is borrowed in the corresponding major mode without necessarily modulating. So I analyze this passage in F# minor like this: corresponding IV - corresponding V - corresponding I - I This is for me a way to understand the progressio using more usual chords than VII and III while still staying in F# minor Hope this helps

Hi, all, I just want to respond to the initial issue raised in this thread, namely, the VII65 in measure 5.  This could, indeed, be analyzed as a ii-half-dim-7 as well.  But I don't hear it that way.  What I hear is a IV-V-I progression (with the III chord - A major chord - as the I).  So, I wanted that to be reflected in the analysis.  Nonetheless, the VII7 chord and the ii-half-dim-65 chords, in this case, are substitutions of each other.  How?  Well, the key of A major (III) is the relative major of F# minor.  It is easy to switch between these keys.  (In fact, the theorist Dieter de la Motte argues that the hardest thing about writing in minor is staying in minor, since it is so easy to leave the key for the relative major.)  So, if we do have a kind of IV-V-I progression happening in the relative major (where III temporary acts as a kind of I), then that VII is acting as the dominant and its substitute would be the ii-half-dim-7. With the hope of pre-empting a logical follow-up question, I'll address it here: why not, then, analyze this as a key change and analyze IV6-V65-I in A major?  Well, because it is so short lived that it is hard to argue that it should be considered an actual key change.  (We also generally see certain strategies for modulations, and those aren't present here.)  Usually, when there is modulation, the new key sticks around for a while - an entire phrase, for instance, would be executed in that key, for instance - so that the composer can really establish that new key in our ears.  That's not the case here.  In fact, that clever little Mozart barely gives us the III chord.  The resolution of the appoggiatura only occurs once he has already moved onto the next chord (the i chord in the second beat).  This bit of the passage is a particularly good example of how harmonic waters can get blurry thanks to chords that have mediant relationships.  Part of the elegance of this passage is the hinting at harmony rather than the stating of it.
